stem: Two angles are supplementary. If one angle measures 65°, what is the measure of the other angle?

choices.rationale: This would be for complementary angles (90° - 65°).
The angles don't have to be equal.

stem: Two angles are complementary. If one angle measures 38°, what is the measure of the other angle?

choices.rationale: This would be for supplementary angles (180° - 38°).
The angles don't have to be equal.

stem: Two lines intersect. If one angle formed measures 42°, what is the measure of its vertical angle?

choices.rationale: This is the adjacent supplementary angle, not the vertical angle.

solutionSteps: Vertical angles are congruent (have equal measures).

stem: Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. If one alternate interior angle measures 75°, what is the measure of the other alternate interior angle?

choices.rationale: Correct: Alternate interior angles are congruent when lines are parallel.
This would be the supplementary angle.

solutionSteps: When parallel lines are cut by a transversal, alternate interior angles are congruent.

stem: Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. If one corresponding angle measures 118°, what is the measure of the other corresponding angle?

choices.rationale: Correct: Corresponding angles are congruent when lines are parallel.

solutionSteps: When parallel lines are cut by a transversal, corresponding angles are congruent.

stem: Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. If one interior angle on the same side of the transversal measures 72°, what is the measure of the other interior angle on the same side?

choices.rationale: Correct: Same-side interior angles are supplementary. $180° - 72° = 108°$.

solutionSteps: Same-side interior angles (co-interior angles) are supplementary when lines are parallel.

stem: An angle measures 3 times its complement. What is the measure of the angle?

choices.rationale: Correct: Let angle = $x$. Then $x = 3(90-x)$, so $x = 270 - 3x$, thus $4x = 270$, giving $x = 67.5°$.
This is the complement, not the angle.
Would make it equal to complement, not 3 times.

solutionSteps: Let the angle = $x$. Its complement = $90° - x$.

stem: Three angles form a straight line. Two of the angles measure 48° and 72°. What is the measure of the third angle?

choices.rationale: Correct: Angles on a straight line sum to 180°. $180° - 48° - 72° = 60°$.
This is the total, not the third angle.
Added angles instead of subtracting from 180°.

solutionSteps: Angles on a straight line sum to 180°.

stem: In the figure, lines $l$ and $m$ are parallel, cut by transversal $t$. If angle 1 measures $(3x + 15)°$ and its corresponding angle measures $(5x - 25)°$, what is $x$?

choices.rationale: Correct: Corresponding angles are equal: $3x + 15 = 5x - 25$, so $40 = 2x$, thus $x = 20$.
Set expressions equal to 180° instead of each other.

stem: The measure of an angle is 30° more than twice its supplement. What is the measure of the angle?

choices.rationale: Correct: Let angle = $x$. Then $x = 2(180-x) + 30$, so $x = 360 - 2x + 30$, thus $3x = 390$, giving $x = 130°$.
This is the supplement, not the angle.
Result exceeds 180°, impossible for this scenario.

solutionSteps: Let the angle = $x$. Its supplement = $180° - x$.
